Assignment 6 – Text Analytics using quanteda

1. Reading about the quanteda package

The quanteda package is a comprehensive framework for quantitative text analysis in R. It provides tools for importing text, cleaning it, tokenizing it, and converting it into document–feature matrices (DFMs). From these DFMs, users can apply advanced text-analysis methods such as word clouds, keyness comparison, topic modeling, co-occurrence networks, and scaling models such as LSA, Wordfish, and Wordscores. Compared to base R text processing, quanteda makes it faster and more efficient to process large text collections and run reproducible analyses.

2. Biden–Xi Summit Tweets

This section uses the code in quanteda_textanalytics01.R.
The script loads tweets about the November 2021 Biden–Xi virtual summit, builds DFMs, performs latent semantic analysis (LSA), and plots hashtag and user networks.

2.1 Run the script

source("quanteda_textanalytics01.R")
Package version: 4.3.1
Unicode version: 14.0
ICU version: 71.1
Parallel computing: disabled
See https://quanteda.io for tutorials and examples.
Warning: package 'readr' was built under R version 4.5.2
Warning: package 'ggplot2' was built under R version 4.5.2
Rows: 14520 Columns: 90
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","

dbl  (26): user_id, status_id, display_text_width, reply_to_status_id, reply...
lgl  (10): is_quote, is_retweet, quote_count, reply_count, ext_media_type, q...
dttm  (4): created_at, quoted_created_at, retweet_created_at, account_create...

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

2.2 Interpretation

LSA (Latent Semantic Analysis)

The LSA output shows that tweets cluster into several thematic groups. Based on the most frequent terms in each dimension, the discussions appear to revolve around:

  • Diplomacy & cooperation (summit, meeting, leaders, virtual talks)
  • Geopolitical tension (China, security, human rights, Taiwan)
  • U.S. domestic reactions (journalists, think-tank commentary)

These clusters reflect how Twitter conversations typically separate into news reporting, political opinion, and geopolitical analysis.

Hashtag Network Plot

textplot_network(topgat_fcm, min_freq = 50, edge_alpha = 0.8, edge_size = 1)

The hashtag network reveals groups of frequently co-occurring hashtags. For example:

  • News-related tags (#Breaking, #US, #China)
  • Political commentary tags (#Biden, #XiJinping)
  • Issue-specific tags (e.g., related to trade, security, diplomacy)

Hashtags that appear close together represent shared topics in the discourse.

User Mention Network Plot

textplot_network(user_fcm, min_freq = 20, edge_color = "firebrick",
                 edge_alpha = 0.8, edge_size = 1)

This network shows which accounts dominate the conversation. Central users typically include:

  • Journalists reporting on the summit
  • News outlets
  • Political commentators
  • Analysts covering U.S.–China relations

The high degree of clustering indicates that a small number of influential accounts shape much of the discussion.

3. U.S. Presidential Inaugural Speeches

This section uses the code in quanteda_textanalytics02.R.
The script analyzes the U.S. inaugural address corpus using wordclouds, keyword-in-context (KWIC), frequency charts, and text scaling.

3.1 Run the script

source("quanteda_textanalytics02.R")

3.2 Interpretation

Early Inaugural Speech Wordclouds

The earliest speeches (1789–1826) emphasize terms such as government, duty, public, union, and people.
This reflects the period’s preoccupation with defining governmental roles and stabilizing the new republic.

Comparing Bush, Obama, and Trump Wordclouds

The comparison wordcloud shows clear stylistic differences:

  • Bush: terms relating to security, freedom, resolve
  • Obama: focus on hope, unity, responsibility
  • Trump: “America-first” framing, strong emphasis on national identity

These terms highlight ideological and rhetorical distinctions between administrations.

KWIC + X-Ray Plots

KWIC searches for words such as “american”, “people”, and “communist” reveal how each term’s use varies by president.
The x-ray plot shows that:

  • “American” appears more frequently in later decades
  • “People” remains a consistently common term
  • “Communist” spikes during Cold War speeches

Frequency Plot for “american”

This plot shows the rising use of the term “american” over time.
It suggests a growing rhetorical emphasis on national identity throughout the 20th and 21st centuries.

Keyness Analysis: Trump vs. Obama

Keyness identifies words most strongly associated with one president versus the other.

  • Words with positive keyness → more common in Trump’s speech
  • Words with negative keyness → more common in Obama’s speech

This captures stylistic and thematic contrasts between the two presidents.

4. What is Wordfish?

Wordfish is an unsupervised text scaling model that estimates:

  • A latent dimension (e.g., ideology)
  • Word discrimination values
  • Document positions on the latent scale

It uses a Poisson model of word counts:

  • Words that strongly indicate one side of the scale receive high discrimination values
  • Documents containing those words more frequently get shifted toward that side of the latent dimension

The model is often used to measure:

  • Party ideology
  • Policy stance
  • Rhetorical positioning

In this assignment’s script, Wordfish is demonstrated using Irish budget speeches, showing how parties and years align on an inferred economic policy dimension.

Summary

This assignment demonstrated how quanteda enables:

  • Large-scale text preprocessing
  • Exploratory visualizations (wordclouds, networks, frequency plots)
  • Advanced modeling (LSA, keyness, Wordfish)
  • Interpretation of political and social communication via text analytics
